questions.text: Which of the following is associated with congenital absence of vas deferens and seminal vesicles?
questions.solution:
Congenital bilateral absence of the vas deferens (CBAVD) and seminal vesicles is strongly associated with Cystic Fibrosis.

Other options:

(A): Tuberous Sclerosis: Seizures, intellectual disability, ash leaf spots, renal angiomyolipomas not affect the vas deferens or seminal vesicles.

(C): Kallman Syndrome: Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism, anosmia, delayed puberty not structural defects like CBAVD.

(D):Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome: 46,XY with female phenotype, undescended testes, absent uterus.but it does not involve the absence of the vas deferens.

Key Takeaway:Cystic Fibrosis

Cause: Mutation in CFTR gene (autosomal recessive).

Key Features: Thick mucus, chronic respiratory infections, malabsorption, infertility in males.

Diagnosis: Sweat test (elevated chloride), genetic testing.

Treatment: Airway clearance, CFTR modulators (ivacaftor), lung transplant (severe cases).

Reference: Nelson textbook of paediatrics

questions.text: Which of the following is the best way to assess adequate response of ventilation during neonatal resuscitation?
questions.solution:
Improvement in HR is the most important indicator to assess adequate response of ventilation during neonatal resuscitation.

Another indicator is Chest rise.

When HR is not rising then we check for Chest rise.then if chest rise is also not there,then we take Ventilation corrective measures.

Incorrect Options:

  • Chest Rise: Chest rise is a useful indicator for assessing if the air is reaching the lungs during ventilation, but it is secondary to the heart rate in terms of evaluating response to ventilation. A lack of chest rise may signal a need for further corrective measures, such as adjusting the airway or improving ventilation technique.
  • Auscultation: Auscultation of lung sounds can help confirm air entry into the lungs, but it is not as reliable or immediate as heart rate improvement when assessing the effectiveness of ventilation during neonatal resuscitation. It may be difficult to accurately hear lung sounds in a newborn, especially during the urgency of resuscitation.
  • Improvement in Color: Improvement in color(e.g., a return to a normal skin tone) is an indirect indicator of effective ventilation. However, changes in color can be slow and not as immediate or specific as heart rate improvement, making it less reliable than monitoring HR.

Key Takeaway:

  • Improvement in heart rate (HR) is the most important indicator to assess the effectiveness of ventilation during neonatal resuscitation.
  • If HR does not improve, the next step is to check for chest rise, and if chest rise is inadequate, corrective ventilation measures should be taken (e.g., adjusting the airway or increasing ventilation pressure).

Reference: Nelson textbook of paediatrics

questions.text: Which amino acid does not need to be restricted in diet in MSUD?
questions.solution:
Maple Syrup Urine Disease (MSUD)

  • AR inheritance
  • Defect in decarboxylation of branched chain Amino acids Valine,Leucine & Isoleucine.

Cause: Low activity of enzyme Branched Chain Alpha Ketoacid Dehydrogenase (BCKA) complex

  • Presents in neonates as poor feeding, dehydration, acidosis, cerebral depression
  • Maple syrup urine dour

Test: Raised serum levels of BAAs(Branched Amino Acids)

In Urine Adding 2,4-DNPH forms yellow-white precipitates.

  • Rx: Hemodialysis/Peritoneal dialysis

Dietary restriction of Branched chain amino acid rich foods.

  • Thiamine supplementation is effective in some cases.

Incorrect Options:

  • Leucine: Leucine is one of the branched-chain amino acids that need to be restricted in the diet of individuals with MSUD. Due to the BCKAD enzyme deficiency, leucine cannot be properly metabolized, leading to toxic accumulation in the blood and urine.
  • Isoleucine: Isoleucine, like leucine, is a branched-chain amino acid and needs to be restricted in the diet of MSUD patients due to impaired metabolism caused by the enzyme defect.
  • Valine: Valine is another branched-chain amino acid that must be restricted in the diet of MSUD patients, as it too accumulates due to the deficient BCKAD enzyme activity.

Key Takeaway:

  • Maple Syrup Urine Disease (MSUD)involves a defect in the metabolism of branched-chain amino acids(leucine, isoleucine, and valine), requiring dietary restriction of these amino acids.
  • Methionine, being a non-branched-chain amino acid, does not need to be restricted in the diet of MSUD patients.
  • Treatment includes dietary management (restricting BCAAs) and sometimes hemodialysisor peritoneal dialysis for acute episodes, as well as thiamine supplementation, which may be effective in some cases.

Reference: Nelson textbook of paediatrics

questions.text: A child was born with the absence of thymus gland and congenital hypoparathyroidism. This is likely to be due to maldevelopment of which of the following structures (An image was given)?

A 5/10 year old male was admitted with complaints of fatigue and joint pains. On examination, a rash was found on the hands as shown in the image.

What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows a rash over the knuckles and extensor surfaces of the fingers, which is characteristic of Gottron's papules, a hallmark of Juvenile Dermatomyositis (JDM).

Other options:

(A): Nodules in Juvenile RA: Juvenile Rheumatoid Arthritis can present with joint pain and systemic symptoms

(C): Osteoarthritis: Joint degeneration, stiffness; rare in children, no rash.

(D): Sclerodactyly: Tight, thickened skin on fingers; seen in systemic sclerosis, no Gottron's papules.

Key takeaways:

Juvenile dermatomyositis (JDM) is the most common inflammatory myositis in children, distinguished by proximal muscle weakness and a characteristic rash.


Reference: Nelson textbook of paediatrics

questions.text: For a preterm child, what is best suited in the absence of breast milk?
questions.solution:
Donor breast milk is the best option because it is human milk, which is better than any artificial or animal milk.

Key Takeaway:

In the absence of breast milk for a preterm infant, the order of suitability is:

Donor milk > Preterm formula feed > Undiluted cow's milk.

questions.text: ACTH is used in the treatment of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Management guidelines of West syndrome - AOCN 2021 Guidelines

Therapy Of Choice: Hormonal Therapy

  • ACTH is the preferred agent
  • High-Dose Regimen) is used: ACTH 150 U/m2 or 6 U/Kg IM OD x 2 weeks
  • If unavailable, high-dose Prednisolone (4 mg/kg/day) for 2 weeks

Vigabatrin= VGB: Given if ACTH/Steroids fail or are Contraindicated

Incorrect Options:

  • JME (Juvenile Myoclonic Epilepsy): JME is typically managed with valproate, levetiracetam, or lamotrigine, not with ACTH. ACTH is not a treatment for juvenile myoclonic epilepsy.
  • Rolandic Epilepsy: Rolandic epilepsy, also known as benign epilepsy with centrotemporal spikes, is a self-limiting condition that usually resolves by adolescence. Treatment is typically not required for most cases, though carbamazepine or oxcarbazepine may be prescribed for intractable cases. ACTH is not used.
  • LGS (Lennox-Gastaut Syndrome): Lennox-Gastaut syndrome is a severe epileptic encephalopathy often managed with multiple medications, including valproate, lamotrigine, and topiramate. While ACTH may sometimes be used, it is not considered the first-line treatment. The mainstay treatment for LGS involves polytherapy with antiepileptic drugs (AEDs) rather than ACTH.

Key Takeaway:

  • West Syndrome(infantile spasms) is primarily treated with ACTH or high-dose steroids like prednisolone, with vigabatrin as an alternative when first-line treatments fail or are contraindicated.
  • ACTH is not used for other forms of epilepsy like JME, Rolandic Epilepsy, or LGS.

Reference: Nelson textbook of paediatrics

Immune memory is a phenomenon that ensures that if a single dose of the DPT vaccine is given and the next dose is delayed by a few months to a year, the immune response is not completely lost. If a catch-up dose or booster dose is administered after 1 year, an almost equivalent immune response is observed.

questions.text: A 2 year old male child was admitted with recurrent bloody stools, atopic dermatitis like rash and petechiae. On CBC, his TLC was normal and platelet count 20000/mm3. What is the next best step to establish the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of a 2-year-old male child with recurrent bloody stools, atopic dermatitis-like rash, petechiae, and thrombocytopenia (platelet count 20,000/mm³) is suggestive of Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome.

The next best step to confirm the diagnosis is Screening for WASp expression.

Incorrect Options:

  • Anti-platelet antibody assessment:
    • Anti-platelet antibodies are assessed in cases of immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP), not for Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome. In WAS, the thrombocytopenia is due to defective platelet production and function rather than an immune-mediated process.
  • Bone Marrow Aspiration:
    • Bone marrow aspiration might show megakaryocytic hyperplasia in cases of WAS due to increased platelet turnover, but it is not the first-line test to confirm the diagnosis. Screening for WASp expression is a more direct and specific test for diagnosing Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome.
  • LFT and RFT:
    • Liver function tests (LFT) and renal function tests (RFT) are not indicated in the initial workup for Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome unless there are clinical signs suggesting liver or renal involvement. These tests would not help in confirming the diagnosis of WAS, which is primarily based on the presence of characteristic symptoms and WASp expression screening.

Key takeaways:


Atopic dermatitis/Eczema in WAS case


Reference: Nelson textbook of paediatrics

questions.text: Not useful in the management of hyperkalemia?
questions.solution:
Incorrect Options:

  • Salbutamol nebulization:
    • Salbutamol(a beta-2 agonist) helps reduce serum potassium levels by promoting the movement of potassium into cells. This makes salbutamol nebulization an effective treatment in the acute management of hyperkalemia.
  • Calcium gluconate:
    • Calcium gluconate is used in hyperkalemia to stabilize the myocardial membrane and prevent cardiac arrhythmias associated with elevated potassium. It doesn't lower potassium levels but helps protect the heart, especially in severe hyperkalemia.
  • Insulin and Dextrose:
    • Insulin and dextrose are used together in the treatment of hyperkalemia. Insulin helps drive potassium into cells, while dextrose prevents hypoglycemia caused by insulin administration. This is a key treatment strategy for lowering serum potassium levels in hyperkalemia.

Key Takeaway:

  • IV Magnesium Sulphateis not commonly used in the management of hyperkalemia because it doesn't directly lower potassium levels or stabilize cardiac function. The other treatments-salbutamol nebulization, calcium gluconate, and insulin with dextrose-are directly involved in addressing the elevated potassium levels or protecting the heart in cases of hyperkalemia.

Reference: Nelson textbook of paediatrics

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common type of ectopic tissue found in Meckel's diverticulum?
questions.solution:
Rule of 2's in Meckel's Diverticulum

  • Seen in 2% population
  • Two times common in F>M - 2:1
  • Presents before 2 years of age
  • 2 inches length
  • Present 2 feet proximal to ileocecal value, along the antimesenteric border

Ectopic tissue common in meckel diverticulum:

Gastric tissue(>50% cases)>Pancreatic tissue>jejunum

Meckel's diverticulum with ectopic gastric mucosa secretes hydrochloric acid (HCl), which can lead to ulceration in the adjacent intestinal mucosa and result in gastrointestinal bleeding.

Reference: Nelson textbook of paediatrics
